g.text: Condensed Matter and Interfaces, Debye Institute for Nanomaterials Science, Utrecht University, P.O. Box 80000, 3508 TA
Electron Microscopy for Materials Science (EMAT), University of Antwerp, Groenenborgerlaan 171, B-2020 Antwerp, Belgium
Organic Chemistry and Catalysis, Debye Institute for Nanomaterials Science, Utrecht University, Universiteitsweg 99, 3584 CG
Electron Microscopy Utrecht, Debye Institute for Nanomaterials Science, Utrecht University, 3584 CH Utrecht, The Netherlands
Nanoscale cation exchange (CE) has resulted in colloidal
nanomaterials that are unattainable by direct synthesis methods. Aliovalent
CE is complex and synthetically challenging because the exchange of an
unequal number of host and guest cations is required to maintain charge
balance. An approach to control aliovalent CE reactions is the use of a single
reactant to both supply the guest cation and extract the host cation. Here, we
triphenylphosphite (TPP), diphenylphosphine (DPP)] as reactants in the
S nanocrystals. We ﬁnd that noncomplexed GaCl
TOP is unreactive. Successful exchange of Cu
complexed with either TPP or DPP. This is attributed to the pivotal role of the Cu
forms at the surface of the nanocrystal at the onset of the CE reaction, which must be such that simultaneous Ga
extraction can occur. This requisite is only met if GaCl
is bound to a phosphine ligand, with a
moderate bond strength, to allow facile dissociation of the complex at the nanocrystal surface. The general validity of this
mechanism is demonstrated by using GaCl
photoluminescence quantum yield 10-fold, while blue-shifting the photoluminescence into the NIR biological window.
This highlights the general applicability of the mechanistic insights provided by our work.
semiconductor nanocrystals, cation exchange, copper sulﬁde, copper gallium sulﬁde, copper indium sulﬁde,
oﬀer a promising alternative to the widely studied
CdX and PbX NCs (X = S, Se, Te), as they consist of
less toxic elements and display exciting optoelectronic
properties, such as photoluminescence (PL) tunability in the
visible to the near-infrared (NIR) spectral window and
localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPR) in the NIR.
Another advantage of these nanomaterials is the wide range of
compositions that can be obtained, ranging from binary to
multinary compounds with up to ﬁve diﬀerent elements.
This makes them a versatile class of materials, oﬀering ample
morphologies and compositions are not easily accessible by
direct approaches due to synthetic limitations, such as the lack
of suitable precursors for multinary compounds.
cation exchange (CE) has emerged as a promising post-
synthetic tool to circumvent these limitations, providing
pathways to NCs and hetero-NCs with compositions,
morphologies, crystal structures, and heteroarchitectures that
the elemental distribution proﬁle of the product NCs (
shell quantum dots) depends on a number of physicochemical
properties, such as the miscibility of the parent and product
This is an open access article published under a Creative Commons Non-Commercial No
redistribution of the article, and creation of adaptations, all for non-commercial purposes.
